26618: Drain Life.author: longwinded
26618: Drain Life.text_parsed:
@BastionQoU
They put in the "not more life than toughness of creature/life of player" clause because you can't drain more than someone has.... It's not a game decision, it's a flavor decision.

It doesn't matter at all for life, because this card precedes multiplayer formats by many, many years. It matters when you try to double-dip by simultaneously killing an annoying critter and gaining massive amounts of life. (For example, if you're playing mono-black, at 2 life, facing down a Serra Angel and a Circle of Protection: Black. You can kill the angel, save yourself, and and gain 4 life, but you can't kill the angel and pump in enough mana to gain a further 8 life.)

The clause was removed from newer descendants because life gain is not that good, it's pricey, and it just makes the text too long. Removing the clause is also not a game decision so much as a text formatting decision.

(For example, if you're playing mono-black, at 2 life, facing down a [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] and a [autocard]Circle of Protection: Black[/autocard]. You can kill the angel, save yourself, and and gain 4 life, but you can't kill the angel and pump in enough mana to gain a further 8 life.)

The clause was removed from newer descendants because life gain is not that good, it's pricey, and it just makes the text too long. Removing the clause is also not a game decision so much as a text formatting decision.

26620: Ball Lightning.author: Silverware
26620: Ball Lightning.text_parsed:
Ball lightning is an amazing card that really fits into red. It can be very risky to play due to pingers who can kill it before it even attacks, and pretty much any card that deals at least one damage at instant speed. Also creatures with firststrike really ruin ball lightnings day. But when you get past all the little problems that can present themselves as threats for ball lightning it is pure undeniable power.

I have seen three ball lightnings hit the field in one turn and it was gg right then and there.
It is one of thouse few older cards that has actully aged well. R&D knows that this card is loved by many, infact that is why it has seen so many reprints and knock offs. Put simply it is a classic.

Also, if you love Ball Lightning and you perfer to play green (possibly for the mana excel) consider groundbreaker.

26636: Remote Isle.author: InternetNinjacy
26636: Remote Isle.text_parsed:
This card, and all the others in this cycle of lands, are better than most people give credit. They are terrible draw in the early game, but mid and late they can be what you need them to be. A tapped land, (it has to have a drawback of some sort) or it's pay two, draw a card. Also not bad (especially good in the other colors).

The only thing is, the pain lands do it a little better. You pay 1 life, and get your land anyway. Also, all FURTHER draws are less likely to be lands. Functionally, doing the same thing this card does. Still, this card, IRL, costs a lot less than the pain lands.

26645: Shock.author: Burningsickle
26645: Shock.text_parsed:
This is why I hate lightning bolt. Lightning bolt has set a stupidly high standard for red burn in the future, that (in my opinion), still hasn't been matched.

3 dmg for 1 cmc is freakishly generous for removal, especially for removal with versatility. Compare this to all other 1 cmc removals from ALL other colors, and you find that it's very hard to find one that is consistently useful.

Compare to Essence Drain Sorin's Thirst, Unsummon, Prey Upon etc etc etc.

Lightning Bolt is too much!

26658: Power Sink.author: achilleselbow
26658: Power Sink.text_parsed:
There was an article on Wizards that explained how the change in rules that converted interrupts to instants (I think it was 6th edition) made this card much less powerful. The way I understand it is that, because interrupts resolved before any more instants could be played, this meant the opponent could only respond to this spell with other interrupts and otherwise couldn't use any mana later in the resolving order to cast instants or use non-interrupt abilities.
For example, let's just assume we both have a ridiculous amount of mana open. I hit you with a burn spell that would bring you down to 0 life. You respond with a Reflect Damage, and you're holding another one with just enough mana left open to cast it, but I Power Sink the first one for 6. Under the new rules, you can simply respond by casting your other Reflect Damage, and it will resolve before my Power Sink does. Under the old rules, however, the Power Sink would resolve first and you would have to tap out right away, leaving you unable to cast your second spell.
So that's how this card was intended to be used - to effectively freeze the stack and ensure that you have the last word. Making it an instant makes it much less useful, though it still retains some of its old value if you use it to counter a sorcery or creature spell.

27245: Bone Harvest.author: Mode
27245: Bone Harvest.text_parsed:
Its that kind of card you don't want to draw early or at least not twice, but which can get surprisingly powerful when it shows up at a convenient moment.

It's basically a slowtrip* that gives you Goblin Recruiter's effect for creatures in your graveyard.
If your opponent doesn't have any means to manipulate your library (e.g. by milling it or shuffling it), this can be a very powerful effect.

Also since you can predict your next couple of draws, cards like Polymorph and Impromptu Raid can become handy.

*A slowtrip is a portmonteau for a particular effect mostly seen on older cards. They work like regular cantrips (which means the spell lets you draw a card when it resolves), yet - as you can tell by taking a look at the card - have this effect delayed until the next turn.

Also since you can predict your next couple of draws, cards like [autocard]Polymorph[/autocard] and [autocard]Impromptu Raid[/autocard] can become handy.

27251: Diabolic Edict.author: Reishyn
27251: Diabolic Edict.text_parsed:
"This card game will take place... ON A BOAT!"
"A... boat?"
"Yes! Ingenious, isn't it?"
"Why a boat?"
"Because... when he loses the card game... we'll... push him over the edge of the boat! ...Into the sea!"
"And what, pray tell, will that accomplish?"
"Well, his hair will be soaked. It will take him hours to dry it."
"Why do we even need to play a card game? Why can't we just push him off the boat?"
"Wha- No! The card game is integral to the plot! The evil plot! Of which I am the evil mastermind!"

They just need to make a card that makes these cards playable.

Nature's Barrier
Enchantment
Abilities of creatures can't be played.
Creatures with power greater than its converted mana cost cannot attack.
Creatures with toughness greater than its converted mana cost cannot block.
Creatures with both power and toughness equal to its converted mana cost cannot attack or block.
Whenever a creature attacks or blocks, it lose all static abilities.
:Add to your mana pool. Spent this mana only to cast creature spells.

(Flying, Shroud etc are static abilities)
27260: Scaled Wurm.text_posted:

Enchantment
